Award.AwardTitle: Replacement and upgrade for an integrated radar, AIS and DSC system for the R/V Neeskay
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an award for support to replace and upgrade critical components of the R/V Neeskay navigational instrumentation. Specifically the Automatic ship Identification System, radar antenna, satellite compass and VHF radio.

Broader Impacts of the award arise from the fact that the equipment would increase the vessels capability to support science and educational programs, historically funded by NOAA, Wisconsin Sea Grant Program, NSF, EPA, and private sector users (e.g. local utilities). Additionally, the safety of operations will be improved. The newer generation radar equipment offers significant improvements in safety through incorporation of computer calculated collision avoidance information via Automated Radar Plotting Aid (ARPA).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The School of Freshwater Sciences at the Great Lakes WATER Institute has operated the Research Vessel Neeskay continuously since 1969. We are an Associate member of UNOLS, and  active participants in the International Joint Commission supported Great Lakes Association of Science Ships.  This project supported an upgrade to the essential navigational systems on board.  These included a new radar system, replacing a 25 year old unit that had become unreliable, along with an Automatic ship Identification System (AIS), a satellite compass, and digital selective calling marine radio (DSC, a part of the Global Marine Distress Signaling System and a part of the international SOLAS treaty).  The Neeskay is the only research vessel on the Great Lakes that operates 12 months of the year.   The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) has supported a Great Lakes research programfor over 40 years. In 2009 UWM created the nation’s first School of Freshwater Sciences (SFS) at the Great Lakes WATER (Wisconsin Aquatic Technology and Environmental Research) Institute, and accepted its first class of students in 2010. The SFS is a graduate only program, offering doctoral, masters and professional science masters degrees. Today the program has approximately 55 students enrolled. Part of the curriculum involves sea-going experience, and consequently the Neeskay has taken on additional educational and instructional duties in support of the graduate curriculum.  The Neeskay supports a very broad range of extramurally funded research projects and grants,with the major sources of support being NOAA, Wisconsin Sea Grant Program, NSF, EPA, NIH, and private sector users (e.g. local utilities).

Modified by: J. Val Klump
